title: Małgorzata Fornalska
text:
Małgorzata Fornalska (<a href="pseudonym">pseudonym</a>: "Jasia"; 8 June 1902 – 26 July 1944) was a Polish <a href="communism">communist</a> activist and anti-<a href="Nazism">Nazi</a> <a href="Resistance%20during%20World%20War%20II">resistance</a> fighter.
Biography.
Fornalska was born in <a href="Fajs%C5%82awice">Fajsławice</a> to a family of communist activists. From 1918, she was a member of the <a href="Social%20Democracy%20of%20the%20Kingdom%20of%20Poland%20and%20Lithuania">Social Democracy of the Kingdom of Poland and Lithuania</a> and the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">Russian Communist Party (bolsheviks)</a> as well as the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Poland">Communist Party of Poland</a>. From July–December 1918 she worked at orphanages in <a href="Saratov">Saratov</a> and <a href="Petrovsk%2C%20Saratov%20Oblast">Petrovsk</a>.
In January 1920, Fornalska returned to Poland and worked for the <a href="Provisional%20Polish%20Revolutionary%20Committee">Provisional Polish Revolutionary Committee</a> together with her brother Aleksander. Later, she studied at the <a href="Sverdlov%20Communist%20University">Sverdlov Communist University</a> and the <a href="International%20Lenin%20School">International Lenin School</a> in <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>.
Fornalska was arrested and imprisoned several times for her communist activity in Poland in the 1930s. After being released in 1939, she went to the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, where she worked with other exiled Polish communists. In the spring of 1942 she was parachuted into Poland, then occupied by <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>, in order to organize the communist resistance against the occupation. She was elected to the <a href="Central%20Committee">Central Committee</a> of the newly formed <a href="Polish%20Workers%27%20Party">Polish Workers' Party</a> and worked as one of the editors of the party's newspaper, "Trybuna Wolności".
On 14 November 1943, Fornalska was arrested by the <a href="Gestapo">Gestapo</a> and imprisoned in <a href="Serbia%20Prison%2C%20Warsaw">Serbia Prison</a>. She was executed by the Germans in the ruins of the <a href="Warsaw%20Ghetto">Warsaw Ghetto</a> on 26 July 1944.
Posthumously, Fornalska was awarded the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Cross%20of%20Grunwald">Order of the Cross of Grunwald</a>, 1st class, in 1948.
